INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.

## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[74, 98, 600, 534]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1\mathrm{u} = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81\mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\)

The base of the cylinder is at a depth of \(0.190 \text{m}\) below the surface of the water. The cylinder has a weight of \(28 \text{N}\) and a cross-sectional area of \(0.0230 \text{m}^2\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 782, 860, 799]]<|/det|> The wire and the central axis of the cylinder are both vertical. The cylinder is in equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 67, 707, 87]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 273, 875, 307]]<|/det|>
The ball is thrown with speed \(u\) from a height of \(1.5 \text{m}\). The ball then hits the ground with speed \(8.7 \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\). Assume that air resistance is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 318, 141, 336]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 494, 819, 514]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 642, 139, 660]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 641, 875, 675]]<|/det|>

<label>(i)</label>

<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 67, 875, 101]]<|/det|>
A child of weight \(330 \text{N}\) is at point X at the top of a slide. The slide is at the edge of a swimming pool, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 107, 816, 282]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[388, 295, 562, 313]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 325, 875, 373]]<|/det|>
The child moves from rest to the lowest point of the slide that is a vertical distance of \(4.0 \text{m}\) below X. The child continues moving towards point Y which is at the end of the slide and a vertical distance of \(1.1 \text{m}\) above the lowest point. The kinetic energy of the child at Y is \(540 \text{J}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 384, 138, 403]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 384, 848, 403]]<|/det|>

difference in gravitational potential energy = .................................................... J [2]

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 605, 853, 623]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 782, 876, 800]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 68, 139, 85]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 274, 876, 306]]<|/det|>
Electromagnetic waves of wavelength \(0.040 \text{m}\) are emitted in phase from two sources X and Y and travel in a vacuum. The arrangement of the sources is shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 560, 552, 577]]<|/det|>

<label>(i)</label>

<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 67, 875, 100]]<|/det|>
Show that the path difference at point Z between the waves from X and Y is \(3.5 \lambda\), where \(\lambda\) is the wavelength of the waves.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 201, 693, 219]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 67, 875, 100]]<|/det|>
One of the results of the \(\alpha\) -particle scattering experiment is that a very small minority of the \(\alpha\) -particles are scattered through angles greater than \(90^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 111, 732, 129]]<|/det|>
State what may be inferred about the structure of the atom from this result.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 288, 626, 306]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 325, 875, 343]]<|/det|>
<form>.................................................................................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 377, 875, 408]]<|/det|>
A radioactive source produces a beam of \(\alpha\) -particles in a vacuum. The average current produced by the beam is \(6.9 \times 10^{-9} \text{A}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 420, 875, 453]]<|/det|>
Calculate the average number of \(\alpha\) -particles passing a fixed point in the beam in a time of 1.0 minute.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 612, 876, 630]]<|/det|>
<form>number = ....................................................... [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 643, 875, 673]]<|/det|>
The \(\alpha\) -particles in the vacuum in **(c)** enter a uniform electric field. The \(\alpha\) -particles enter the field with their velocity in the same direction as the field.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 686, 875, 717]]<|/det|>
State and explain whether the magnitude of the acceleration of an \(\alpha\) -particle due to the field decreases, increases or stays constant as the \(\alpha\) -particle moves through the field.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 789, 875, 807]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 67, 843, 85]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 97, 583, 115]]<|/det|>
Both of the nuclei are in the same uniform electric field.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 127, 875, 159]]<|/det|>
State and explain whether the magnitude of the electric force acting on nucleus X is greater than, less than or the same as that acting on nucleus Y.
